activities.title:
When we started doing AI takeoffs, some people called us mad. 

All we knew was that we had a deep understanding of the market and their pain. And we…

We lit Huang Engineering Quad at Stanford on fire. If you don't believe me, just look at the pictures.

I'm excited to share that my team and I won…

This Valentine’s Day was NOT spent alone. 

4 freshmen. 36 hours of coding. 7 showers (Chandra Suda forgot one). It turns out today's CS majors can…

I've wrapped up my 1st quarter at Stanford! 

This quarter has been nothing short of surprises, fun, late nights, and new experiences. Here are some…

🚨Mercor is hiring Junior Software Engineers (remote)🚨

• $50-$90 an hour
• Fully remote and asynchronous
• Have 1+ years of software engineering…

people_also_viewed.summary:
James Dancer
        
              
          We're seeing a move beyond LLMs and Generative AI. OpenAI and Microsoft and others have built great models, operating right at the frontier of the compute and transformer architectures presently available. Software coding and natural language interfaces will never be the same again. Equally, we've seen phenomenally smart models from groups like Google DeepMind, some of which will have impact on how science itself is carried out.

But LLMs and non-expert models are the wrong tool for applied AI at scale. The competition is now for better, high-quality data, relevant for expert niches in domains from materials and engineering to pharma and health. That data is often proprietary, hard to access and sometimes highly regulated. You can't scrape it from the internet, and it's not just 'content' you can license - data on patients, molecules, and engine performance are much more tightly held than Getty Images or articles from the Financial Times.

As important as the data, every group building applied AI will need experts in those domains - clinicians, biologists, engineers - who have been additionally trained in AI and computer science. The brief era of generalist computer science folk doing work in expert domains is fast closing. Teams have to understand what data is important, how to collect it, what it means, and how to exploit it operationally, and an ontology and infrastructure to match. And then those teams will need to do the difficult job of turning models into functional products, which lead to concrete real world outcomes, in domains which are hard to change. All of that is a heck of a lot harder than building a big model and adding a user interface, however complex the underlying computer science. 

The shift is now to synthetic rather than generative AI. That work will be centred in research institutions like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, The Francis Crick Institute or the University of Oxford - where I advise folk doing work along these lines. It will require close partnerships with global corporations and institutions, from Novo Nordisk to Rolls-Royce, and with hyper scale tech groups like Amazon Web Services (AWS), as routes to both data and scale. And it will need global investors like DCVC, Sofinnova Partners, Sequoia Capital, 8VC and Index Ventures to help build the new wave of expert-led applied AI ventures.

There's more to come on this from places like Oxford and global investors. We see and strongly support others moving in the same direction, across the US, Europe and close allies. (And we should all move beyond the dated 'US vs Europe' narrative - there is really just one, connected capital and talent pool for this work. The work is too important to make it a transatlantic competition.)

Tanmay Dhote
        
              
          Yann LeCun recently shared an insightful piece of advice for students aspiring to shape the future of AI:

"Don't work on LLMs. This domain is dominated by large companies with massive capital and data resources. Instead, focus on developing next-gen AI systems that overcome the limitations of current LLMs."

As we acknowledge the vast resources required for LLM development, it's crucial to explore alternative methods. 

What could these next-gen AI systems look like?

Jennie Montano, MSEE

"Further proof that no one knows anything about AI and we’re just making up the rules as we go: 2 Emory students win $10K cash prize *from Emory* for creating AI homework help tool. Emory then suspends students because tool “could be used for cheating.” / via Wall Street Journal."

Technology, education, and policy fronts are all moving or being moved to embrace, harness, grapple with, and/or regulate what is undeniably a cultural and generational-changing tool. 

Thoughts?

Jai Toor
        
              
          What would the topics of the "Missing Semester of Your Industry's Education" be?

If you're not familiar, there's an MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) class called "The Missing Semester of Your CS Education" which covers key non-academic skills to work in CS - like vim, shell/CLI scripting, Git version control, how to use a debugger, etc. - which are extremely helpful for the real world, but nowhere in modern CS education.

What would those be for your job?

For data/analytics:
1. Git is still the #1 undisputed champ. 
2. SQL Window functions - indistinguishable from magic or the root cause of all errors
3. Database explain plans - or the related topic, emotional recovery from accidentally spending $10k on a bad query
4. Cherry picking - these narratives won't justify themselves

What am I missing?

Darlene Damm
        
              
          Reversible Computing:    "In reversible computing, instead of running a calculation in only one direction (inputs followed by outputs) and then feeding the output to a new calculation and running it again, the computing can be done in both directions (known as “time-reversible” computing). Effectively, energy is retained inside the chip instead of being released as heat. The theory is that this method would generate negligible amounts of heat, vastly reducing energy consumption."

Rohit Pakalapati
        
              
          CBO Interviews: Mladen M. Hoyss on Shaping the Future of Nothing OS | https://lnkd.in/eFyYx9n6

Getting the chance to talk with Mladen was a surreal opportunity, and I’m truly grateful to the Nothing community for choosing me to be their voice. It’s moments like these that bring my journey full circle.

My history with Mladen’s work goes back to the early days of Blloc. While I couldn’t use the Zero18 phone, I’ve been following Blloc since the beginning. I got into the closed beta testing of Ratio, their minimalist launcher. At that time, I was heavily addicted to my smartphone. Ratio had a profound impact on my usage habits, significantly reducing my screen time. I was so impressed that I continued using it across three to four different phones, often proudly sharing screenshots of my reduced screen time on social media.

When I heard about Mladen M Hoyss joining Nothing I thought, “This is a collaboration that was bound to happen.” The transition from Ratio to Nothing OS has been an evolution in my smartphone experience. It’s fascinating to see how Mladen’s philosophy has been integrated into a more comprehensive and fun environment at Nothing while still maintaining the core principles of mindful technology use.

This interview has not only provided insights into Nothing’s design philosophy, but also allowed me to connect the dots in my personal journey with mindful technology use. I’m excited to see how Nothing continues to evolve and grateful for the opportunity to be part of this community-driven conversation about the future of technology.

#NothingCommunity #NothingOS

Harry Stebbings
        
              
          I’ve been fortunate enough to do AI shows with Sam Altman, Yann LeCun & Arthur Mensch.

But this show today with David Cahn at Sequoia Capital is the best of all of them:

🧠 AI’s $600BN question

🏃 Why no one will never train a frontier model on the same data center twice

🏗️ Servers, steel & power: The 3 pillars of the future of AI

Not one to be missed, my 8 key takeaways 👇

1. The Oligopoly That is Blowing Billions on AI 

- Microsoft, Azure, & Google now represent $7T market cap.
- Of course they will spend billions to protect their oligopoly
- What is most interesting is Meta is the only incumbent that is financing this not with cloud being their cash cow.

2. How Startups Could Win with the Cost of Compute Coming Down

- Big tech companies are producers of compute & startups are consumers of compute.
- Overproduction of compute = lower prices. 
- This gives startups higher margins & makes them more valuable. 

3. Is Compute the Currency of the Future or Do the Costs Come Down and It Is Commoditised?

- We are forgetting “compute” is a euphemism for a $2BN data center in the middle of nowhere.
- They have GPUs & liquid cooling systems that need to be constantly optimized & upgraded.
- We cannot simply build 15 years worth of compute all at once.  No one's ever going to train a frontier model on the same data center twice.

4. Data Centre Teams and Model Teams Need to Be Coupled

- You cannot have separate teams running data centers & building models.
- Elon & Zuck control all their data centres.
- It will not work as these models get better & better.

5. Why the Data Center Is the Most Important Asset

- There is not much difference between these models today.
- AI researchers are jumping from one lab to another.
- Scaling laws will become more dominant as these models get bigger.

6. Servers Steel and Power: The Three Bottlenecks of AI

Three things:
1. Servers: NVIDIA, AMD, Broadcom…
2. Steel: Construction & real estate developers for data centers.
3. Power: All the energy required for AI.
- More factories will be built in 12 months for AI and we will see another industrial revolution.

7. You Have to Have a Cash Machine to Play the Big Model Game

- Amazon has AWS
- Meta has Instagram
- Microsoft has Azure
- You need a cash machine to compete and it CANNOT be the AI business.

8. There is One Definition of Success in Venture: Are you a Slugger?

- If you are generating billion dollar gains, you are a slugger.
- Doug Leone, Pat Grady, Andrew Reed are all sluggers.
- You cannot be good at this business without being a slugger.

(links in comments)

#founder #funding #business #investing #vc #venturecapital #entrepreneur #startup #seed #funding #sequoia

Angelo Anthony
        
              
          As LLM's get increasingly more sophisticated, with OpenAI's o1 model now including reflection before answering, I am increasingly investigating the emergence of autonomous AI Agents. My path here was somewhat circuitous in that I was going through Y Combinator's Summer 24 cohort which had a plethora of AI use cases that were very industry specific. I found that curious in that earlier SaaS offerings should have already automated and/or digitized most of these process, and I couldn't figure out why AI startups would focus on basic workflows such as inventory management and book keeping. As I dove into the matter, with the help of my now indispensable Perplexity, I landed on a very insightful post by Bessemer Venture Partners (https://lnkd.in/gHtQQRha). The thesis is that Vertical AI  companies are going to be magnitudes bigger than general solutions, especially as they focus on industries that were earlier inaccessible to SaaS given very high language based workflows. Within that thesis, there was also a mention of AI Agents and how these would come to dominate workflow automation going forward. This neatly tied in with a great conversation between Peter H. Diamandis and Emad Mostaque (https://lnkd.in/g-ccxbma) that talked about 10 billion agents!! 

I have spent the last few weeks diving into AI Agents with the help of content from interesting voices such as Adam Silverman (Hiring) and David Ondrej. Over the next few months, I will try to create and deploy AI Agents on some basic use cases to get hands on experience on these systems. In the meantime, I will close this post with a link to a video from Andrew Ng, a pioneer in AI systems that provides a short overview of AI Agents (https://lnkd.in/g8v4pUQu). I hope you enjoy the content and wish everyone a productive week ahead.

Dr Mark van Rijmenam, CSP
        
              
          As AI reshapes our workforce, it promises to uplift the fortunate while it discards the vulnerable, potentially carving deeper economic divides. 😱

➡️ The relentless advance of AI technology brings a dual-edged sword to the labor market. A recent White House report highlights a stark division: AI could enhance productivity for some workers while completely obliterating jobs for others. 

➡️ Notably, 20% of Americans are employed in sectors highly susceptible to AI disruption. Particularly at risk are lower-income, less educated workers, whose simpler, routine tasks are easily automated. 

➡️ This technological shift might boost efficiency and cut costs, but at what social cost? As AI streamlines operations, it will widen the income inequality gap, benefiting predominantly higher-educated individuals in high-earning roles and the shareholders of companies implementing AI. 

❓ The real challenge lies not just in harnessing AI's capabilities but in mitigating its potentially divisive impact on society. Will the future of work reflect enhanced opportunities for all, or a heightened barrier for the less privileged?

Read the full story on Business Insider: https://lnkd.in/gJ3k7hgP

#AI #JobMarket #Redundant #FutureofWork #Jobs

Neal Ghosh
        
              
          🚨🚨 🚨  Unlocking Innovation: The Power of the Adjacent Possible 

Innovation programs can stall when the team tries to ideate way beyond their collective perspective and frame of reference. Like a software engineer brainstorming genetic modification of mycelia, or a senior executive ideating process improvements which they haven't been participated in for decades.

It's challenging, exhausting, and ultimately self-defeating. 

Enter the concept of the "Adjacent Possible" - a game-changer for innovation. What is it?

The Adjacent Possible, coined by Stuart Kauffman, represents the realm of new ideas within reach based on our current knowledge, resources, and capabilities.

Why it matters:

➡️ Realistic Innovation: it focuses on achievable advancements, not far-fetched concepts.

➡️ Incremental Progress: each innovation opens doors to new possibilities.

How to leverage it:
• Constantly explore the boundaries of your adjacent possible. What's in your line of sight is what you know best.

• Combine existing ideas in novel ways. Even small perturbations from status quo can generate large innovation leaps.

• Stay curious about developments in adjacent industries. Cross-domain patterns create fresh sources of ideas, while also expanding the adjacent possible.

Most of all, it takes the 'genius' pressure off the team. No one knows everything, but each one of us knows a lot about something, and we can all drive plenty of innovation potential by focusing on the spaces we know best.

Are you exploring your Adjacent Possible? Share your thoughts below! 👇

#Innovation #innovationsystems #AdjacentPossible

Jeffrey Paine
        
              
          Here are the top 3 most promising startup ideas I identified from the interview with John Schulman (OpenAI) by Dwarkesh Patel.

1.  AI-powered coding assistant that can understand high-level instructions, write code, test it, and iterate to complete entire coding projects with minimal human involvement. e.g. Devin, Github Co-pilot

2. AI system that can read and understand all the scientific literature in a field, sift through data, and help accelerate research by assisting human scientists and making new discoveries. e.g. Iris.ai

3. AI assistant that works alongside a human on their computer, understands the full context of the project they are working on, proactively makes suggestions, and performs work in the background. e.g. Adept AI

https://lnkd.in/d5umCuhd

Niek Verkoelen
        
              
          SpaceX blew my mind again with their latest Starship launch last week!

If you haven't been following, SpaceX has mastered the art of rockets landing themselves, which once seemed impossible.

They’ve done this hundreds of times with their current rockets.

But Starship? It’s a game-changer.

Bigger than the Apollo moon rockets, designed to carry up to 100 people, and aimed at colonising Mars!

Fully reusable – taking off, landing, and doing it all over again. Incredible, right?

What’s even cooler is SpaceX’s approach.

They iterate like a software company. Instead of spending years and massive budgets on a single rocket, they build, launch, explode, learn, and repeat.

Think of it as a series of MVPs leading to the final product.

Last week, they successfully launched Starship, with both stages landing back in the ocean. And next time?

They’re planning to catch the rocket with massive arms on the launch tower, dubbed Mechazilla. Wild!

From an engineering and business perspective, SpaceX’s achievements are mind-blowing.

Sending 100 people to Mars? It’s a sci-fi dream turning into reality.

Remember the cramped Apollo missions? Now we’re looking at multiple launches with hundreds of people.

Watching a rocket the size of an apartment building land itself and get caught by a tower – it’s straight out of a sci-fi movie. And it’s happening right now.

Inspiring stuff!

What do you think?

#spacex #innovation #spacetravel

Tracy Karanja
        
              
          🚀 Week 2 Recap: Headstarter AI SWE Fellowship Journey! 🚀

I’m excited to share what I’ve been up to in my second week as part of the Headstarter AI Software Engineering Fellowship!

Week 1: Started off strong by learning how to build a portfolio website, thanks to the incredible guidance from Yasin Ehsan 🚀. His insights and support have been invaluable in crafting a standout portfolio.

Week 2: I dove into a new project – building a Pantry Tracker application! 🍽️ The tracker is a comprehensive tool for managing pantry inventory with features such as:

Add/Remove Items: Easily add or remove items with real-time updates.
Update Quantities: Adjust item quantities as needed.
Search Functionality: Quickly find items in your pantry.

Technologies Used: Leveraged React and Next JS for the frontend, Firebase for real-time database management, and Material UI for a sleek, responsive UI. The app integrates CRUD operations for a seamless user experience.
Thanks to Bill Zhang for his guidance on this project.

Here is the link to the desktop website if you're curious: https://lnkd.in/dydirkvC

And the github: https://lnkd.in/dfSWnVrR

🔗 Special Mentions:
Speakers: I had the privilege of attending an online panel discussion with industry leaders:
Dennis, Founder of Foursquare, with insights on scaling a $150M revenue company.
Tariq, the first SWE at Applovin, sharing his journey through a $30Bn IPO.
Julian, Ex-Meta SWE and Intern CEO of Wisdolia, discussing his path in tech.
Hamza, CEO of Olostep, who’s currently hiring Headstarter fellows.


Feeling grateful for these learning experiences and the opportunity to connect with such inspiring professionals! Here’s to continued growth and innovation. 🌟
#HeadstarterFellowship #SoftwareEngineering #PantryTracker #TechCommunity #Networking #Innovation

Baris Aksoy
        
              
          The best things come in small packages 👝

🚨 Pay attention to the rise of Small Language Models (SLMs)! They will become important going forward: 

1️⃣ Efficiency: SLMs achieve comparable or superior performance to LLMs with fewer parameters. Microsoft's new Phi-3 series outperforms larger models on benchmarks like MMLU & MT-bench (Google: https://lnkd.in/gn5zYZHg 
Microsoft: https://lnkd.in/ghK8fm7V
Meta: https://lnkd.in/gkbM7pGs)

2️⃣ Specialization: Trained on curated, high-quality datasets. With 3.8B-14B parameters & advanced datasets, these transformer decoder models match GPT-3.5's capabilities in a compact form. Accurate benchmarking/eval will be important.

3️⃣ Interpretability: Neurons in SLMs are easier to analyze, improving model transparency. 

4️⃣ Cost-effective: Less resource-intensive (vs training large models)

I have a chance to meet a few exciting startups here. Reach out if you are working on this space 🙋🏻‍♂️ 

#startups #llm #slm #smalllanguagemodels #phi3 #largelanguagemodels #gpt4 #google #gemma #llama3 #ai #ml #edgeai

awards.summary: The President’s Volunteer and Service Award is one of the most prestigious awards bestowed by the US Presidential Office to honor volunteer service.

awards.name: Congressional App Challenge
awards.summary: 2022: Honored 2nd Place by U.S. Representative Steve Womack for my mobile app "WorldAI - Flutter App utilizing YOLO Computer Vision for Object Detection" womack.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=4059992021: Honored 3rd Place by U.S. Representative Steve Womack for my mobile app "Plant-I: Plant Disease Detection Using Artificial Neural Networks" womack.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=405213

awards.name: CyberPatriot State Champions (Team Captain)
awards.summary: Team captain of "Cyber Coldiers" team, placing 1st overall in the Platinum division (highest) in Arkansas. Specialized in securing Linux (Ubuntu and Fedora) and networking systems.

awards.name: Hugh O'Brian Youth Leadership Award Recipient
awards.organization: Hugh O'Brian Youth Leadership Award Recipient
awards.summary: Selected as a student ambassador during my sophomore year for strong leadership abilities.

awards.name: 1st Place @ State FBLA Mobile App Development
awards.summary: 1st place at the 2022 Future Bussiness Leaders of America (FBLA) Arkansas State Leadership Conference for Mobile Applications Development.

awards.name: 1st Place (2x) @ Arkansas State Technology Student Association (TSA) Competition
awards.summary: 1st place for Prepared Presentation and Biotechnology Design: "A novel ML-based protein analysis and prediction of bioreactor organisms towards low-cost, efficient food manufacturing for space exploration"
